title: RL33517
content: Under the Impoundment Control Act of 1974, the President can propose to rescind funding from an appropriations act by sending a special message to Congress. If Congress does not approve the rescission within 45 days, the funding must be made available for executive agencies. President George W. Bush advocated for a line-item veto to address excessive earmark projects. The President advocated for a line-item veto in his State of the Union address in 2006 to address excessive earmark projects. An Administration draft bill, the Legislative Line Item Veto Act of 2006, was sent to Congress, proposing expedited rescission where at least one house must vote on the proposals. Enhanced rescission, available under the Line Item Veto Act of 1996, favored the President by creating a presumption in spending reductions identified in special presidential messages. Under the Line Item Veto Act of 1996, the "enhanced rescission" altered the framework to favor the President, making spending reductions identified in special presidential messages permanently cancelled unless Congress enacts a disapproval bill. Expedited rescission bills focus on procedural changes in Congress to ensure immediate consideration of the President's rescission request. Congressional approval is still necessary, but fast-track procedures encourage an up-or-down vote on the proposal. The expedited rescission approach involves fast-track procedures in Congress to encourage an up-or-down vote on the President's spending reduction proposal. It is seen as transferring less power from Congress to the President compared to other approaches modifying the ICA framework. In the past, the House passed expedited rescission bills annually, with specific limitations on proposed rescissions. The expedited rescission approach in Congress allows for fast-track procedures to vote on the President's spending reduction proposal. In the 103rd Congress, H.R. 1578 passed by the House in 1993 had no limit on the amount that could be rescinded, allowing the President to request rescission of 100% of a program's funding. This bill also included provisions for expedited judicial review and detailed fast-track procedures for expedited consideration of a rescission's substitute. H.R. 1578 and H.R. 4600 in the 103rd Congress detailed fast-track procedures for expedited rescission measures, allowing submission of special rescission messages and proposing the repeal of targeted tax benefits within 20 days following enactment. Additionally, a draft expedited rescission bill titled the Legislative Line Item Veto Act of 2006 was introduced, which aimed to amend the Impoundment Control Act to grant the President new legislative line item veto authority. The Administration bill proposed to amend the Impoundment Control Act by inserting a new "Part C -- Legislative Line Item Veto," granting the President authority to propose rescission of discretionary budget authority, direct spending items, or targeted tax benefits in a special message to Congress. The President would have flexibility in submitting and packaging these messages, with no time constraints and the ability to include multiple rescissions in a single message. The Legislative Line Item Veto Act allows the President to propose rescissions of budget authority or direct spending in special messages to Congress. There are no time constraints, and multiple rescissions can be included in one message. Rescission requests would be considered under fast-track procedures, with specific timelines for introduction, committee review, and final passage. It allows the President to withhold budget authority proposed for rescission or suspend the execution of direct spending for up to 180 days.
